question:
Name a reproductive strategy in which parasites take advantage of the care of other individuals of the same species or different species to raise their young.

SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• Brood parasitism is a reproductive strategy in which a parasite relies on another species (or individuals of the same species) to raise its offspring.
  • In this method, the parasitic organism lays its eggs in the nest of a host and the host unknowingly raises the young.
  • A well-known example is the cuckoo bird, which lays eggs in the nests of other birds like crows or warblers.
  • The host bird incubates the egg and feeds the chick, often at the cost of its own young.

Additional Information:

  • Sexual parasitism is seen in some deep-sea fish where males attach to females permanently.
  • Kleptoparasitism involves stealing food gathered by others.
  • Competitive parasitism is not a recognized scientific term in reproductive biology.

question:
Identify an organism that exhibits metagenesis.

SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Obelia is a marine coelenterate (Cnidarian) that exhibits metagenesis, i.e., alternation of generations.
  • It shows a life cycle with both asexual (polyp) and sexual (medusa) phases.
  • The polyp reproduces asexually to give rise to medusae, which in turn produce gametes for sexual reproduction.
  • This cycle allows Obelia to survive and reproduce in varied environmental conditions.
  • Metagenesis is a hallmark feature of many cnidarians, not seen in sponges.

Additional Information:

  • Spongilla, Sycon, and Euspongia are poriferans (sponges) which do not exhibit metagenesis.
  • Sponges reproduce both sexually and asexually, but without alternation of distinct generations (no polyp-medusa stages).
  • Obelia is commonly found attached to substrates in shallow marine environments.

question:
The period of life, when the body undergoes chages leading to reproductive maturity is called _______ .

SSC MTS 04/05/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The period of life when the body undergoes physical, hormonal, and emotional changes that lead to reproductive maturity is called adolescence.
  • It typically occurs between the ages of 10 and 19 years and marks the transition from childhood to adulthood.
  • Key changes include puberty, development of secondary sexual characteristics, and emotional shifts.
  • Adolescence is regulated by hormones like testosterone and estrogen in males and females respectively.

Additional Information:

  • Maturity refers to the state of being fully grown, not the phase leading to it.
  • Cloning is a form of asexual reproduction, unrelated to human developmental stages.
  • Budding is an asexual reproduction method seen in organisms like Hydra and yeast.

question:
The stage of the embryo in which all the body parts can be identified is called ______ .

SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The stage of the embryo in which all the body parts can be identified is called the foetus.
  • In humans, this stage typically begins after the 8th week of pregnancy.
  • At this point, major organs, limbs, and features become visible, though still developing.
  • The foetus continues to grow and mature inside the uterus until birth.
  • This stage follows the zygote (fertilized egg) and embryo stages.

Additional Information:

  • Uterus is the organ where the foetus develops, not a developmental stage.
  • Ovulation is the release of an egg from the ovary, unrelated to embryo development.
  • Zygote is the single-cell stage formed after fertilization.

question:
Breeding of fish in specially constructed tanks and ponds is called _______ .

SSC MTS 12/05/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The breeding, rearing, and harvesting of fish in specially designed tanks or ponds is known as pisciculture.
  • Pisciculture is a branch of aquaculture and plays a vital role in fish production and food supply.
  • It involves both freshwater and marine fish farming, depending on the species and setup.
  • Commonly bred fishes include rohu, catla, and hilsa in India.
  • It contributes to livelihood, nutrition, and the economy in many rural areas.

Additional Information:

  • Viticulture is the cultivation of grapes.
  • Horticulture is the cultivation of fruits, vegetables, and ornamental plants.
  • Sericulture is the rearing of silkworms for silk production.

question:
Which of the following is NOT an example of “viviparous” animals?

SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Viviparous animals are those that give birth to live young instead of laying eggs.
  • Examples include mammals like dogs, cats, and cows, where the embryo develops inside the mother's body.
  • Birds, on the other hand, are oviparous – they lay eggs, and development occurs outside the mother's body.
  • Hence, birds are not viviparous, making option (a) correct.

Additional Information:

  • Viviparous animals provide internal nourishment to the developing embryo.
  • Oviparous animals include birds, reptiles, amphibians, and most fish.
  • Some exceptions exist, like certain species of sharks and reptiles, which may show ovoviviparity.

question:
The transformation of the larva into an adult through drastic change is called ________ .

SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• The process by which a larva transforms into an adult with drastic structural and physiological changes is called metamorphosis.
  • It is commonly observed in organisms like frogs, butterflies, and insects.
  • Metamorphosis can be of two main types:
    • Complete metamorphosis (e.g., butterfly: egg → larva → pupa → adult)
    • Incomplete metamorphosis (e.g., grasshopper: egg → nymph → adult)
  • It plays a crucial role in the life cycle and development of many invertebrates and amphibians.

Additional Information:

  • Budding is an asexual mode of reproduction seen in organisms like Hydra and yeast.
  • Shifting and bulging are not recognized biological processes related to development.

question:
How many arteries are there in an umbilical cord?

SSC CGL 13/08/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• The umbilical cord is a structure that connects the developing fetus to the placenta in the womb.
  • It typically contains two umbilical arteries and one umbilical vein.
  • The two arteries carry deoxygenated blood and waste from the fetus to the placenta.
  • The single vein brings oxygenated, nutrient-rich blood from the placenta to the fetus.
  • Thus, the number of arteries in a normal umbilical cord is two.

Additional Information:

  • The presence of only one artery (single umbilical artery) may indicate congenital abnormalities.
  • The umbilical cord is surrounded by Wharton's jelly, which protects the blood vessels.

question:
_______ is the ability of a single cell to produce a fertile, adult individual.

SSC CGL 17/08/2021 (1st shift)
solution:
• Totipotency is the ability of a single cell to develop into a complete, fertile, adult organism, including all types of cells and tissues.
  • In plants, any living cell, particularly meristematic or parenchymatous cells, can potentially express totipotency.
  • This concept was proven by F.C. Steward in carrot experiments, where a single plant cell regenerated into a full plant.
  • Totipotency is the basis of plant tissue culture techniques.

Additional Information:

  • Pluripotency refers to the ability to form many, but not all, cell types (not a full organism).
  • Cloning involves producing genetically identical individuals, not necessarily from a single totipotent cell.
  • Mutation is a change in DNA, unrelated to the developmental potential of a cell.

question:
The phenomenon whereby the female gamete undergoes development to form new organisms without fertilization in some organisms like honey bees, some lizards and birds is called:

SSC CPO 25/11/2020 (Evening)
solution:
• The phenomenon in which a female gamete (egg cell) develops into a new organism without fertilization is called parthenogenesis.
  • It occurs naturally in some species of honey bees, lizards, birds, and other invertebrates.
  • In honey bees, for example, unfertilized eggs develop into male drones through parthenogenesis.
  • This is a form of asexual reproduction, yet it involves a gamete rather than somatic cells.
  • It allows for reproduction without male involvement in certain species.

Additional Information:

  • Budding is a form of asexual reproduction where a new organism grows from the body of the parent (e.g., Hydra).
  • Fragmentation is reproduction through splitting of the body into parts that develop into new individuals (e.g., Planaria).
  • Apomixis is a type of asexual reproduction in plants, where seeds are formed without fertilization.

question:
Which of the following is the primary sex organ in females?

SSC CGL 06/03/2020 (1st shift)
solution:
• The ovary is the primary sex organ in females.
  • It performs dual functions:
    • Producing female gametes (ova or eggs)
    • Secreting sex hormones like estrogen and progesterone
  • Females have two ovaries, located on either side of the uterus.
  • These hormones regulate the menstrual cycle, secondary sexual characteristics, and pregnancy preparation.
  • Other organs like the fallopian tubes, uterus, and vagina are secondary reproductive structures.

Additional Information:

  • Fallopian tube transports the egg from the ovary to the uterus and is the site of fertilization.
  • Uterus is where the fertilized egg implants and develops.
  • Vagina is the birth canal and passage for menstrual flow.

question:
During puberty, a woman’s first menstrual flow is known as _________ .

RRB Group-D 29/08/2022 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The first menstrual flow in a girl during puberty is called menarche.
  • It marks the onset of reproductive capability in females and usually occurs between the ages of 10 to 15 years.
  • Menorrhagia refers to excessive or prolonged menstrual bleeding.
  • Amenorrhea is the absence of menstruation, either naturally (e.g., pregnancy) or due to medical conditions.
  • Menopause is the permanent cessation of menstruation, usually occurring between 45 to 55 years of age.

Additional Information:

  • Menarche is influenced by nutrition, genetics, and overall health.
  • Psychological and physical changes like breast development and pubic hair growth usually accompany menarche.
  • Regular menstrual cycles may take time to establish after menarche.

question:
Which of the following is a disadvantage of using contraceptive pills?

RRB Group-D 07/10/2022 (Shift-III)
option_1: They may produce hormonal imbalance.
option_2: Both partners in a couple must take pills.
option_3: They can cause menopause.
option_4: The effect of the pills is irreversible.
solution:
• One of the main disadvantages of using contraceptive pills is that they can cause hormonal imbalance in the body.
  • These pills contain synthetic hormones (estrogen and/or progesterone) that interfere with the natural hormonal cycle to prevent ovulation.
  • While effective in preventing pregnancy, they may cause side effects such as mood swings, nausea, weight gain, and irregular periods.
  • Options (b), (c), and (d) are incorrect:
    • (b) Only the female partner needs to take the pill, not both.
    • (c) Pills do not cause menopause; menopause is a natural age-related process.
    • (d) The effect of contraceptive pills is reversible—fertility usually returns after stopping them.

Additional Information:

  • Long-term use should be under medical supervision.
  • Other safer or non-hormonal contraceptive options include condoms, copper IUDs, etc.
  • Hormonal pills may also be used to manage conditions like PCOS or irregular cycles, under prescription.

question:
What is the best diet for a pregnant woman?

RRB Group-D 29/09/2022 (Shift-I)
option_1: A special diet prescribed by a dietician
option_2: A diet rich in proteins and vitamins
option_3: Diet rich in Ghee
option_4: Adding iron supplements to a high calorie diet
solution:
• The best diet for a pregnant woman is a specialized diet prescribed by a qualified dietician or doctor, tailored to her individual health, nutritional needs, and stage of pregnancy.
  • While a diet rich in proteins, vitamins, iron, and minerals is essential, it must be balanced and adjusted for weight, medical history, and any complications.
  • Only eating ghee or adding iron to a high-calorie diet without professional guidance may lead to nutritional imbalances or health issues.
  • A personalized plan ensures proper fetal growth, maternal health, and prevents conditions like anemia, gestational diabetes, or hypertension.

Additional Information:

  • Common elements of a pregnancy diet:
    • Iron, folic acid, calcium, and protein supplements
    • Fresh fruits, green leafy vegetables, whole grains, and dairy
    • Limited intake of caffeine, sugars, and processed foods
  • Regular medical check-ups and nutritional monitoring are crucial during pregnancy.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a part of the female reproductive system?

RRB Group-D 30/08/2022 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The female reproductive system consists of organs involved in reproduction, ovum production, fertilization, and childbirth.
  • It includes:
    • Ovaries – produce eggs and hormones
    • Fallopian tubes – transport eggs from ovaries to uterus
    • Uterus – site where the fertilized egg implants and develops
  • The urethra, however, is part of the urinary system, not the reproductive system. It carries urine from the bladder to the outside of the body and has no role in reproduction in females.

Additional Information:

  • In males, the urethra serves both urinary and reproductive functions, but in females, it is strictly urinary.
  • The vagina, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries form the core reproductive organs in females.
  • Proper understanding of these parts is essential for reproductive health awareness.

question:
Oral contraceptive pills work by stopping __________ .

RRB Group-D 18/08/2022 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Oral contraceptive pills primarily work by preventing ovulation, which means stopping the release of an egg from the ovary.
  • These pills contain synthetic hormones (estrogen and/or progesterone) that trick the body into thinking ovulation has already occurred.
  • Without ovulation, fertilization cannot happen, since there's no egg available for the sperm.
  • While some pills may alter the uterine lining or thicken cervical mucus, their primary mechanism is to stop ovulation.

Additional Information:

  • Pills must be taken regularly and correctly for effective pregnancy prevention.
  • Missing pills or inconsistent use can reduce their effectiveness.
  • Other contraceptive methods, like IUDs, may act by preventing implantation, but that is not the main action of oral pills.

question:
Is there a visible difference between sperms which contain X chromosomes and sperms which contain Y chromosomes?

RRB Group-D 27/09/2022 (Shift-I)
option_1: No, there is no difference in size but there is difference in motility
option_2: No, there is no difference in size or motility.
option_3: Yes, the Y-containing sperms are motile.
option_4: Yes, the X-containing sperms are larger.
solution:
• Sperms carrying X and Y chromosomes appear identical under a microscope—there is no visible difference in terms of size or shape.
  • Though some scientific studies suggest minor differences in motility or weight, these are not visibly detectable and are not consistent or significant enough to distinguish between them.
  • Therefore, in practical and clinical terms, there is no difference in size or motility between X- and Y-bearing sperms.

Additional Information:

  • A sperm carrying an X chromosome results in a female child (XX), while a sperm carrying a Y chromosome results in a male child (XY) upon fertilization.
  • Gender determination in humans is done by the male sperm, not the female egg (which always carries X).
  • Claims about choosing gender based on sperm type are scientifically unreliable and ethically discouraged.

question:
Which of the following statements is incorrect about AIDS?

RRB Group-D 19/09/2022 (Shift-I)
option_1: The virus can pass on to person from an infected person by sharing the syringes used for injecting drugs.
option_2: The virus can be transmitted through sexual content with a person infected with HIV.
option_3: The virus can be transmitted to an infant form the infected mother through her milk.
option_4: The virus can be transmitted by shaking hands with a person infected with HIV.
solution:
• AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) is caused by the HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus), which weakens the immune system.
  • It spreads through specific bodily fluids such as blood, semen, vaginal fluids, and breast milk.
  • Correct statements:
    • (a) Sharing infected syringes can transmit the virus.
    • (b) Unprotected sexual contact with an infected person is a common mode of transmission.
    • (c) HIV can pass from an infected mother to child via breast milk.
  • Incorrect statement:
    • (d) HIV is not spread by casual contact like shaking hands, hugging, sharing utensils, or touching. Hence, this statement is incorrect.

Additional Information:

  • HIV cannot survive long outside the human body.
  • There is no cure for AIDS, but antiretroviral therapy (ART) helps manage the infection.
  • Preventive measures include safe sex practices, screening of blood, and using sterile syringes.

question:
What is the basic event in reproduction?

RRB Group-D 24/08/2022 (Shift-III)
solution:
• The basic event in reproduction is the replication of DNA, as it ensures that genetic information is accurately passed from one generation to the next.
  • During reproduction, whether asexual or sexual, DNA must duplicate so that each new cell or offspring receives the correct set of instructions for growth and functioning.
  • While cell division (like mitosis or meiosis) is involved, it follows DNA replication.
  • Protein synthesis and RNA replication are essential cellular processes but not the fundamental step in reproduction.

Additional Information:

  • DNA replication occurs during the S-phase of the cell cycle.
  • In asexual reproduction, the replicated DNA is copied directly to the new cell.
  • In sexual reproduction, DNA from both parents combines after replication to form a new individual.

question:
Which of the following is the INCORRECT feature related to animal reproduction?

RRB Group-D 24/08/2022 (Shift-III)
option_1: Seminal vesicle is a gland present in human males
option_2: Regeneration is not the same as reproduction
option_3: In Amoeba, splitting of two cells takes place in any plane
option_4: Fertilization of egg takes place in the uterus in human female
solution:
• The incorrect statement is:

    (d) Fertilization of egg takes place in the uterus in human female.

  • In humans, fertilization occurs in the fallopian tubes, not in the uterus. The fertilized egg then travels to the uterus for implantation.
  • Correct statements:
    • (a) The seminal vesicle is a gland present in human males that produces seminal fluid.
    • (b) Regeneration is a process of regrowing lost body parts and is different from reproduction.
    • (c) In Amoeba, cell division (binary fission) can occur in any plane, making statement (c) correct.

Additional Information:

  • Fertilization site is crucial in reproductive biology and affects early embryonic development.
  • The uterus provides a nurturing environment for the embryo after implantation.

question:
In human males, why are tests present outside the abdominal cavity in a pouch called scrotum?

RRB Group-D 22/08/2022 (Shift-III)
option_1: It helps in maintaining low pressure than the body for sperm formation
option_2: It secretes hormones for sperm formation
option_3: It helps in maintaining temperature 2-3 degrees lower than the body for sperm formation
option_4: It is richly supplied by blood vessels needed for sperm formation
solution:
• In human males, the testes are located outside the abdominal cavity in a pouch called the scrotum because sperm formation requires a temperature 2-3°C lower than the normal body temperature.
  • The scrotum helps maintain this lower temperature, which is essential for the proper development and maturation of sperm.
  • If testes were inside the abdominal cavity, the higher body temperature would inhibit sperm production.
  • Options (a), (b), and (d) are incorrect or less relevant compared to temperature regulation.

Additional Information:

  • The scrotum can contract or relax to bring testes closer or away from the body to regulate temperature.
  • Proper temperature control is crucial for fertility.
  • Some animals have internal testes and different mechanisms for temperature control.

question:
Sexual reproduction in human beings involves the introduction of sperm in the vagina of the female. Where does fertilization occur ?

RRB Group-D 28/09/2022 (Shift-III)
option_4: In the fallopian tube
solution:
• In human beings, fertilization occurs in the fallopian tube, not in the vagina, uterus, or cervix.
  • After sexual intercourse, sperm travel through the vagina, cervix, and uterus to reach the fallopian tube.
  • The egg released from the ovary meets the sperm in the fallopian tube, where fertilization takes place.
  • The fertilized egg then moves to the uterus for implantation and development.

Additional Information:

  • The fallopian tube provides the ideal environment for sperm and egg to meet.
  • Fertilization is a critical step initiating the formation of a new individual.
  • Issues in fallopian tubes can cause infertility or ectopic pregnancy.

question:
Which part of the human sperm is responsible for determination of sex of the zygote?

RRB Group-D 30/09/2022 (Shift-III)


https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749539722792_image001.png
option_3: Part A and B
option_4: Part B and C
solution:
• In the given diagram of a human sperm,
    • Part A is the head, which contains the nucleus carrying the genetic material (chromosomes).
    • The sex of the zygote is determined by the chromosomes present in the sperm’s nucleus (Part A).
  • Therefore, Part A only is responsible for determining the sex of the zygote.
  • Part B is the mid-piece, containing mitochondria for energy, and Part C is the tail for movement, neither involved in sex determination.

Additional Information:

  • The sperm can carry either an X or a Y chromosome, which determines the sex of the offspring (XX for female, XY for male).
  • The egg always carries an X chromosome.
  • The union of sperm and egg chromosomes forms the genetic sex of the zygote.

question:
Girls should take special care with respect to health and hygiene during the time menstrual flow to avoid infections and ill health. Which of the following statements in this regard is false?

RRB Group-D 26/08/2022 (Shift-III)
option_1: Girls should keep trace of their menstrual cycle and be prepared for the onset of mensuration.
option_2: Girls should consume chips and packed or tinned snacks to meet nutritional needs.
option_3: Girls should use sanitary napkins or clean homemade pads.
option_4: Girls should change pads after every 4-5 hours or as per the requirement.
solution:
• The false statement is:

    (b) Girls should consume chips and packed or tinned snacks to meet nutritional needs.

  • During menstruation, girls should eat nutritious, balanced diets rich in vitamins, minerals, and proteins to maintain health and energy.
  • Consuming junk food like chips and processed snacks can lead to poor nutrition, indigestion, and worsen menstrual discomfort.
  • The other statements (a), (c), and (d) are true and promote good menstrual hygiene and health.

Additional Information:

  • Proper menstrual hygiene helps prevent infections such as urinary tract infections or reproductive tract infections.
  • Tracking the menstrual cycle helps in early preparation and managing menstrual symptoms better.
  • Changing pads regularly prevents bacterial growth and odor.

question:
Which of the following is an example of an ovarian hormone?

RRB Group-D 18/09/2022 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Estrogen is an example of an ovarian hormone produced by the ovaries in females.
  • It plays a key role in the development of female secondary sexual characteristics and regulation of the menstrual cycle.
  • Testosterone is a male sex hormone primarily produced in the testes.
  • Adrenalin is a hormone produced by the adrenal glands, involved in the fight-or-flight response.
  • Thyroxine is a hormone produced by the thyroid gland, regulating metabolism.

Additional Information:

  • Estrogen also helps in preparing the uterus for pregnancy.
  • Other ovarian hormones include progesterone, which works alongside estrogen.
  • Hormonal imbalance involving estrogen can cause menstrual irregularities and other health issues.

question:
The nutrients are supplied to the foetus from the mother through:

RRB Group-D 22/09/2022 (Shift-III)
solution:
• The nutrients are supplied to the foetus from the mother through the placenta.
  • The placenta is a specialized organ that connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall and facilitates the exchange of nutrients, oxygen, and waste products between mother and fetus.
  • The cervix is the lower part of the uterus and does not supply nutrients.
  • The zygote is the fertilized egg and does not play a role in nutrient transfer.
  • Endosperm is a tissue in seeds of plants, not related to human reproduction.

Additional Information:

  • The placenta also produces hormones that support pregnancy.
  • Proper functioning of the placenta is vital for fetal development.
  • Problems with the placenta can lead to complications like low birth weight or premature birth.

question:
Voice change during puberty occurs due to ____________ .

RRB Group-D 01/09/2022 (Shift-II)
option_2: The development of lungs
option_4: The development of larynx
solution:
• Voice change during puberty occurs primarily due to the development of the larynx (voice box).
  • During puberty, the larynx grows larger and the vocal cords become longer and thicker, leading to a deeper and more resonant voice, especially in males.
  • Cigarette smoking can affect the voice but is not the cause of voice change during puberty.
  • Lung development and muscular development influence breathing and strength but are not the direct causes of voice change.

Additional Information:

  • The growth of the larynx is influenced by hormones like testosterone in males.
  • This voice change is a secondary sexual characteristic of puberty.
  • In females, the larynx also grows but to a lesser extent, causing a subtler voice change.

question:
What specializations are found in the germ cells of sexually reproducing animals with complex body designs?

RRB Group-D 01/09/2022 (Shift-I)
option_1: Male germ cell – large with food store, Female-small and motile
option_2: Male germ cell-small with food store, Female-large and motile
option_3: Male germ cell – small and motile, Female – large with food store
option_4: Male germ cell – large and motile, Female – small with food store
solution:
• In sexually reproducing animals with complex body designs, the male germ cells (sperms) are generally small and motile to actively swim towards the female germ cells.
  • The female germ cells (eggs or ova) are large and contain food stores (nutrients) to support the early development of the embryo after fertilization.
  • Therefore, the correct specialization is:

    (c) Male germ cell – small and motile, Female – large with food store.

Additional Information:

  • The motility of sperm helps in reaching the egg for fertilization.
  • The food store in the egg provides energy for the zygote before it can establish nutrient intake from the mother.
  • These specializations increase the chances of successful reproduction.

question:
The reproductive parts in animals produce male and female gametes that fuse to form a:

RRB NTPC Stage-II 12/06/2022 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The male and female gametes produced by the reproductive parts of animals fuse during fertilization to form a zygote.
  • The zygote is the first cell of a new organism, formed by the union of sperm and egg.
  • The zygote undergoes cell division and development to eventually become an embryo and later a foetus.
  • Ovum refers to the female gamete (egg) itself, not the product of fusion.

Additional Information:

  • Fertilization restores the diploid number of chromosomes in the zygote.
  • The zygote represents the start of a new individual’s development.
  • Proper fusion and development are critical for successful reproduction.

question:
Which option correctly shows the path that the sperms take when they are released from the human male reproductive system?

RRB Group-D 25/08/2022 (Shift-III)
option_1: Testis – Ureter – Urethra – Penis
option_2: Testis – Vas deferens – Ureter – Penis
option_3: Testis – Vas deferens – Urethra – Penis
option_4: Testis – Ureter – Vas deferens – Penis
solution:
• The correct path that sperms take when released from the human male reproductive system is:

    Testis → Vas deferens → Urethra → Penis.

  • Sperms are produced in the testes, then travel through the vas deferens.
  • From the vas deferens, sperms enter the urethra, which runs through the penis and releases sperm outside the body during ejaculation.
  • The ureter is part of the urinary system and carries urine from the kidneys to the bladder, not involved in sperm transport.

Additional Information:

  • The vas deferens is a muscular tube that transports sperm from the epididymis to the urethra.
  • Along the way, seminal fluid from glands mixes with sperm to form semen.
  • Proper functioning of this pathway is essential for male fertility.
